awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Submarine record of disastrous earthquakes at a strain partitioned transpressional boundary: Haiti 2010 and 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
Two earthquakes, M7.0 and M7.2, ruptured sections of the transform fault along Haiti’s southern peninsula in 2010 and 2021. During this project a marine survey in Jamaican waters offshore the recent earthquakes will be conducted to investigate the tectonic and sedimentary effects of these and previous earthquakes in the same region. Sediment cores and high-resolution sub-bottom mapping will image active faults and sample earthquake-triggered sediment deposits. The overarching goal of the project is to compare the new images and samples with pre-existing data collected by the French in 2012 and by collaborators from Jamaica. Results of the project will help improve understanding of fault movement and the character of earthquake-generated sediment deposits and provide insight into the complexities of this plate boundary and the associated hazards. Some key evidence, such as sediment suspended in abyssal water and isotopes that date the remobilized sediments, are short-lived.  Other records can be obliterated by erosion.  Because of this, the project is time sensitive.  Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained during the project.


Continental transform boundaries cross heavily populated regions, and as in the M7.0 2010 and M7.2 2021 Haiti earthquakes, ruptures along these boundaries can cause catastrophic damage and loss of life. Transform boundaries can accommodate only modest changes in relative motion, even slightly oblique motion can make them transpressional or transtensional. These boundaries can evolve into complex, often poorly constrained, systems of faults. The Enriquillo-Plantain Garden Fault (EPGF) is the main strand of a sinistral E-W transform along the southern boundary of the Gonave microplate. The eastern EPGF traces a prominent ridge that forms the 250 km long southern peninsula of Haiti and is rooted on a belt of thrust faulting. The 2010 M7.0 & 2021 M7.2 sequences ruptured the eastern and western segments of this ridge, respectively. Both sequences feature mainshocks that were nearly transcurrent, and thrust after-shocks primarily to the north and west. Such coupling between distinct faults repeated in two earthquake sequences along the same boundary strongly suggests that these faults form a single strain-partitioned, transpressional fault system. The results of the study will constrain whether this system extends to the Jamaica Passage, whether it generates similar large earthquakes in the submarine part of the boundary now loaded by recent earthquakes in Haiti, and the fidelity of the sedimentary record for EPGF earthquakes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas Institute for Geophysics

por.por_cntn:
Several large historical earthquakes have occurred along the EPGF near Haiti (e.g., 1751, 1770, 2010; Ali et al., 2008; Bakun et al., 2012), however, anomalously few have occurred in the west, near Jamaica. It is very likely, however, that a large >Mw7.0 earthquake will occur near the capital city of Jamaica in the next few decades. For example, detailed GPS studies by DeMets & Wiggens-Grandison (2007), conducted before both the Haiti 2010 and 2021 events, indicate significant accumulation of elastic strain in the western half of the EPGF across Jamaica that in 2007 were capable of releasing a Mw 7.2 earthquake Kingston Jamaica represents a mirror image of Port-au-Prince: it is the capital of the island nation of Jamaica, is home to 1.3 million people (nearly half of Jamaica’s population) and sits at the western terminus of the same deadly fault that killed >200,000 people in 2010. Prehistoric earthquakes have not been previously reported along the EPGF in the Jamaica Passage. The Port Royal earthquake of June 7, 1692 caused 2000 casualties, extensive liquefaction and subsidence. The Great Kingston earthquake occurred January 14, 1907 caused 1000 casualties, fires and extensive destruction of buildings. No prior detailed geological, structural, or paleoseismic study has occurred on the western half of the plate boundary to assess either the geomechanical coupling offshore or pending seismic hazard. By studying the recent earthquakes along this fault system, both the effects and geologic record of the 2010 and 2021 Haiti earthquakes in the Jamaica passage and comparing these results to paleoseismic events offshore Jamaica, we can seek to construct a complete record of seismicity, and assess the hazard in this region. 

We were highly successful in obtaining a sedimentation record of historic and prehistoric earthquakes in Jamaica Basin and in the Jamaica Passage Basins (Morant, Navassa and Matley) and in beginning to address fault partitioning in transpressive plate boundaries. To identify event deposits, we conducted a multi-proxy approach using: age dating (short-lived radioisotopes and radiocarbon), X-ray fluorescence elemental analyses at 1 mm intervals, physical properties (bulk density and magnetic susceptibility), core descriptions, photos and core X-rays within the context of multibeam bathymetry and MCS images. There is great confidence in the radiocarbon ages since we obtained similar ages from the same intervals using both planktonic and benthic foraminifers. 

1)     We identified the 1907 AD Great Kingston earthquake event deposits in two cores located 100 km apart in Kingston Basin. The ages were obtained from gamma counting of xs210Pb with a half-life of 22.3 years. 

2)     We dated and identified event deposits related to the Port Royal 1692 AD earthquake in two cores located 100 km apart in Kingston Basin. These radiocarbon ages were obtained at NOSAMS Woods Hole and they were calibrated to years BP and AD and BC using Stuvier and Reimer 1993 radiocarbon calibration software. 

3)     Five additional event deposits were dated with C-14, correlated in at least two cores and linked with possible prehistoric earthquakes at: 1215 AD (720 BP), 682 AD (1268 BP), 2500 BP, 3750 BP, 3900 BP allowing a reconstruction of earthquake ruptures along the EPGF for the past several millennia as suggested in our proposal. 

4)     The 3750 and 3900 BP event deposits documented for Kingston Basin in two cores spaced 100 km apart were also documented in Morant Basin and the easternmost Matley Basin. The fact that event deposits of the same age were documented along the EPGFZ in basins located >200 km apart addresses one of the main objectives of this proposal to better understand fault partitioning along transpressional plate boundaries. More MCS work is required for better understanding fault ruptures since radiocarbon ages cannot resolve 10 to 100-year age differences. Issues such as coupling between distinct faults repeated in two earthquake sequences along the same boundary need to be further investigated to understand if these faults form a single strain- partitioned, transpressional fault system or not.

5)     The EPGFZ is clearly active along the Jamaica Passage. East to West MCS profiles of Morant Basin show the seafloor expression of the EPGFZ manifested as a steep scarp with relief ranging from 6 to 23 m. 

6)     Event deposits were identified in Morant Basin in the upper 1m of two cores at:  3300, 3900, 4200, 4600, 4900, 5000.

7)     The longer-term record of event deposits is spaced 5 to 10 ky apart in a 4 m long core of the Morant Basin depocenter.  The C-14 cal ages are: 18 ky BP, 26 ky BP, 33ky BP and 42ky BP. A more detailed chronology is needed to better understand this variability between the event deposits of the upper meter and the longer-term event deposits and why some are closely spaced in time (~300 years vs a much longer time space of 5 to 10 ky). 


Last Modified: 03/06/2023
Modified by: Sean S Gulick
